papers.title: Representing Numbers in NLP: a Survey and a Vision
papers.venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Avijit Thawani,J. Pujara,Pedro A. Szekely,Filip Ilievski
papers.summary: This work synthesizes best practices for representing numbers in text and articulate a vision for holistic numeracy in NLP, comprised of design trade-offs and a unified evaluation.

papers.title: I NVESTIGATING THE L IMITATIONS OF T RANSFORM ERS WITH S IMPLE A RITHMETIC T ASKS
papers.summary: It is concluded that modern pretrained language models can easily learn arithmetic from very few examples, as long as they use the proper surface representation, which bolsters evidence that subword tokenizers and positional encodings are compo-nents in current transformer designs that might need improvement.

papers.title: Reasoning with Transformer-based Models: Deep Learning, but Shallow Reasoning
papers.venue: Conference on Automated Knowledge Base Construction
papers.authors: Chadi Helwe,C. Clavel,Fabian M. Suchanek
papers.summary: This survey paper discusses the performance of transformers on different reasoning tasks, including mathematical reasoning, commonsense reasoning, and logical reasoning.

papers.title: A Survey of Deep Learning for Mathematical Reasoning
papers.authors: Pan Lu,Liang Qiu,Wenhao Yu,S. Welleck,Kai-Wei Chang
papers.summary: This survey paper reviews the key tasks, datasets, and methods at the intersec-tion of mathematical reasoning and deep learning over the past decade, and evaluates existing benchmarks and methods and discusses future research directions.

papers.title: Investigating Numeracy Learning Ability of a Text-to-Text Transfer Model
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: K. Pal,Chitta Baral
papers.summary: This work investigates the ability of text-to-text transfer learning model (T5), which has outperformed its predecessors in the conventional NLP tasks, to learn numeracy, and considers four numeracy tasks.

papers.title: Relational World Knowledge Representation in Contextual Language Models: A Review
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Tara Safavi,Danai Koutra
papers.summary: This work proposes to organize knowledge representation strategies in LMs by the level of KB supervision provided, from no KB supervision at all to entity- and relation-level supervision, and provides a high-level, extensible taxonomy for knowledge representation in L Ms.

papers.title: QA Dataset Explosion: A Taxonomy of NLP Resources for Question Answering and Reading Comprehension
papers.authors: Anna Rogers,Matt Gardner,Isabelle Augenstein
papers.summary: This study is the largest survey of the deep learning models in NLP field to date, providing an overview of the various formats and domains of the current resources, and highlighting the current lacunae for future work.

papers.title: Benchmarks for Automated Commonsense Reasoning: A Survey
papers.authors: E. Davis
papers.summary: A survey of the development and uses of AI commonsense benchmarks, and it is argued that it is worthwhile to invest the work needed ensure that benchmark examples are consistently high quality.

papers.title: PAL: Program-aided Language Models
papers.authors: Luyu Gao,Aman Madaan,Shuyan Zhou,Uri Alon,Pengfei Liu,Yiming Yang,Jamie Callan,Graham Neubig
papers.summary: Program-Aided Language models (P A L): a novel approach that uses the LLM to read natural language problems and generate programs as the intermediate reasoning steps, but ofﬂoads the solution step to a runtime such as a Python interpreter.

papers.title: Reasoning with Language Model Prompting: A Survey
papers.authors: Shuofei Qiao,Yixin Ou,Ningyu Zhang,Xiang Chen,Yunzhi Yao,Shumin Deng,Chuanqi Tan,Fei Huang,Huajun Chen
papers.summary: This paper provides a comprehensive survey of cutting-edge research on reasoning with language model prompting and introduces research works with comparisons and summaries and provides systematic resources to help beginners.

papers.title: Teaching Autoregressive Language Models Complex Tasks By Demonstration
papers.authors: Gabriel Recchia
papers.summary: The results suggest that fine-tuning autoregressive language models on small sets of well-crafted demonstrations may be a useful paradigm for enabling individuals without training in machine learning to coax such models to perform some kinds of complex multi-step tasks.

papers.title: Chain of Thought Prompting Elicits Reasoning in Large Language Models
papers.authors: Jason Wei,Xuezhi Wang,Dale Schuurmans,Maarten Bosma,E. Chi,Quoc Le,Denny Zhou
papers.summary: Experiments on three large language models show that chain-of-thought prompting improves performance on a range of arithmetic, commonsense, and symbolic reasoning tasks.

papers.title: Towards Reasoning in Large Language Models: A Survey
papers.authors: Jie Huang,K. Chang
papers.summary: A comprehensive overview of the current state of knowledge on reasoning in large language models, including techniques for improving and eliciting reasoning in these models, methods and benchmarks for evaluating reasoning abilities, and suggestions on future directions are provided.

papers.title: Commonsense Reasoning with Implicit Knowledge in Natural Language
papers.venue: Conference on Automated Knowledge Base Construction
papers.authors: Pratyay Banerjee,Swaroop Mishra
papers.summary: This work takes a middle ground where it uses smaller language models together with a relatively smaller but targeted natural language text corpora and proposes four methods competitive to state-of-the-art methods to reason with implicit commonsense.

papers.title: A Primer for Neural Arithmetic Logic Modules
papers.authors: Bhumika Mistry,K. Farrahi,Jonathon Hare
papers.summary: Focusing on the shortcomings of NALU, an in-depth analysis is provided to reason about design choices of recent units to highlight inconsistencies in a fundamental experiment causing the inability to directly compare across papers.

papers.title: Exploring the Learning Mechanisms of Neural Division Modules
papers.authors: Bhumika Mistry
papers.summary: It is shown that robustly learning division in a systematic manner remains a challenge even at the simplest level of dividing two numbers, and a novel approach to division is proposed which is called the Neural Reciprocal Unit (NRU) and the Neural Multiplicative Reciproc Unit (NMRU).

papers.title: Do Language Models Understand Measurements?
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Sungjin Park,Seung-kook Ryu,E. Choi
papers.summary: This study shows that PLMs lack the capability required for reasoning over measurements, and proposes a simple embedding strategy to better distinguish between numbers and units, which leads to a significant improvement in the probing tasks.

papers.title: Dissociating language and thought in large language models: a cognitive perspective
papers.authors: Kyle Mahowald,Anna A. Ivanova,I. Blank,N. Kanwisher,J. Tenenbaum,Evelina Fedorenko

papers.title: Identify, Align, and Integrate: Matching Knowledge Graphs to Commonsense Reasoning Tasks
papers.venue: Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Lisa Bauer
papers.summary: This work presents an approach to assess how well a candidate KG can correctly identify and accurately fill in gaps of reasoning for a task, which is called KG-to-task match and demonstrates that ATOMIC, an event-inference focused KG, is the best match for SIQA and MCScript2.0, and that the taxonomic ConceptNet and WikiHow-based KGs are the bestmatch for PIQA across all 3 analysis phases.

papers.title: COM2SENSE: A Commonsense Reasoning Benchmark with Complementary Sentences
papers.authors: Shikhar Singh,Nuan Wen,Yu Hou,Pegah Alipoormolabashi,Te-Lin Wu,Xuezhe Ma,Nanyun Peng
papers.summary: This work introduces a new commonsense reasoning benchmark dataset comprising natural language true/false statements, with each sample paired with its complementary counterpart, resulting in 4k sentence pairs, and proposes a pairwise accuracy metric to reliably measure an agent’s ability to perform Commonsense reasoning over a given situation.

papers.title: TIMEDIAL: Temporal Commonsense Reasoning in Dialog
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Lianhui Qin,Aditya Gupta,Shyam Upadhyay,Luheng He,Yejin Choi,Manaal Faruqui
papers.summary: This paper presents the first study to investigate pre-trained LMs for their temporal reasoning capabilities in dialogs by introducing a new task and a crowd-sourced English challenge set, TimeDial, and reveals that the models fail to reason about dialog context correctly; instead, they rely on shallow cues based on existing temporal patterns in context.

papers.title: Predicting Numerals in Natural Language Text Using a Language Model Considering the Quantitative Aspects of Numerals
papers.venue: Workshop on Knowledge Extraction and Integration for Deep Learning Architectures; Deep Learning Inside Out
papers.authors: Taku Sakamoto,Akiko Aizawa
papers.summary: This paper measures the NCS acquired by existing neural language models using a masked numeral prediction task as an evaluation task and proposes methods to reflect not only the symbolic aspect but also the quantitative aspect of numerals in the training of language models, using a loss function that depends on the magnitudes of the numerals and a regression model for the masked numal prediction task.

papers.title: Self-Attention Networks Can Process Bounded Hierarchical Languages
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Shunyu Yao,Binghui Peng,C. Papadimitriou,Karthik Narasimhan
papers.summary: It is proved that self-attention networks can process Dyck-(k, D), the subset of Dyck-k with depth bounded by D, which arguably better captures the bounded hierarchical structure of natural language.

papers.title: Towards Tractable Mathematical Reasoning: Challenges, Strategies, and Opportunities for Solving Math Word Problems
papers.authors: Keyur Faldu,A. Sheth,Prashant Kikani,Manas Gaur,Aditi Avasthi
papers.summary: This work inspects non-neural and neural methods to solve math word problems narrated in a natural language, and highlights the ability of these methods to be generalizable, mathematically reasonable, interpretable, and explainable.

papers.title: A Survey on Multi-hop Question Answering and Generation
papers.authors: Vaibhav Mavi,Anubhav Jangra,A. Jatowt
papers.summary: A general and formal definition of MHQA task is provided, the existing attempts to this highly interesting, yet quite challenging task are summarized, and the best methods to createMHQA datasets are outlined.

papers.title: Augmenting Operations Research with Auto-Formulation of Optimization Models from Problem Descriptions
papers.authors: Rindranirina Ramamonjison,Haley Li,Timothy T. Yu,Shiqi He,Vishnu Rengan,Amin Banitalebi-Dehkordi,Zirui Zhou,Yong Zhang
papers.summary: An augmented intelligence system for simplifying and enhancing the modeling experience for operations research is described that receives a suggested formulation of an optimization problem based on its description and enables the users to validate and edit the suggestions.

papers.title: A Causal Framework to Quantify the Robustness of Mathematical Reasoning with Language Models
papers.authors: Alessandro Stolfo,Zhijing Jin,K. Shridhar,B. Schölkopf,Mrinmaya Sachan
papers.summary: This work proposes a novel framework, which pins down the causal effect of various factors in the input, e.g., the surface form of the problem text, the operands and math operators on the output solution, and shows that robustness does not appear to continuously improve as a function of scale, but that the recent GPT-3-Instruct achieves a dra-matic improvement in both robustness and sensitivity, compared to all other GPT variants.

papers.title: Program of Thoughts Prompting: Disentangling Computation from Reasoning for Numerical Reasoning Tasks
papers.authors: Wenhu Chen,Xueguang Ma,Xinyi Wang,William W. Cohen
papers.summary: Under both few-shot and zero-shot settings, PoT can show an average performance gain over CoT by around 12% across all the evaluated datasets, and by combining PoT with self-consistency decoding, can achieve SoT performance on all math problem datasets and near-SoTA performance on ﬁnancial datasets.

papers.title: A Categorical Archive of ChatGPT Failures
papers.authors: A. Borji

papers.title: Applying Structural and Dense Semantic Matching for the ARQMath Lab 2022, CLEF
papers.venue: Conference and Labs of the Evaluation Forum
papers.authors: Wei Zhong,Yuqing Xie,Jimmy J. Lin
papers.summary: This work describes the participation of the team in the ARQMath 2022 Lab, where two highly complementary methods for effective math answer and formula retrieval are applied, using a lexical sparse retriever and a fine-tuned bi-encoder dense retriever to capture contextual similarity and semantic matching.

papers.title: Evaluating Transformer Language Models on Arithmetic Operations Using Number Decomposition
papers.venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation
papers.authors: Matteo Muffo,A. Cocco,Enrico Bertino
papers.summary: The ability of Transformer Language Models to perform arithmetic operations following a pipeline that, before performing computations, decomposes numbers in units, tens, and so on is evaluated.

papers.title: Development of a Neural Network-Based Mathematical Operation Protocol for Embedded Hexadecimal Digits Using Neural Architecture Search (NAS)
papers.authors: Victor Robila,Kexin Pei,Junfeng Yang
papers.summary: A comparison between human-developed machine learning model and models sampled through Neural Architecture Search (NAS) determine an efficient approach to solve the problem of addition using embedded hexadecimal digits.

papers.title: Towards Robust Numerical Question Answering: Diagnosing Numerical Capabilities of NLP Systems
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Jialiang Xu,Mengyu Zhou,Xinyi He,Shi Han,Dongmei Zhang
papers.summary: This paper proposes to conduct numerical capability diagnosis on a series of Numerical Question Answering systems and datasets and investigates the effectiveness of applying perturbations as data augmentation to relieve systems’ lack of robust numerical capabilities.

papers.title: Logical Tasks for Measuring Extrapolation and Rule Comprehension
papers.authors: Ippei Fujisawa,R. Kanai
papers.summary: This work describes and characterize logical tasks and discusses system requirements for their solution, and discusses the relevance of logical tasks to concepts such as extrapolation, explainability, and inductive bias.

papers.title: Teaching Algorithmic Reasoning via In-context Learning
papers.authors: Hattie Zhou,Azade Nova,H. Larochelle,Aaron C. Courville,Behnam Neyshabur,Hanie Sedghi
papers.summary: This work shows that it is possible to teach algorithmic reasoning to LLMs via in-context learning, which it is referred to as algorithmic prompting, and evaluates the approach on a variety of arithmetic and quantitative reasoning tasks, and demonstrates boosts in performance over existing prompting techniques.

papers.title: Transformers Learn Shortcuts to Automata
papers.authors: Bingbin Liu,J. Ash,Surbhi Goel,A. Krishnamurthy,Cyril Zhang
papers.summary: The theoretical results completely characterize shortcut solutions, whereby a shallow Transformer with only o(T ) layers can exactly replicate the computation of an automaton on an input sequence of length T .

papers.title: MemPrompt: Memory-assisted Prompt Editing with User Feedback
papers.authors: Aman Madaan,Niket Tandon,Peter Clark,Yiming Yang
papers.summary: It is shown how a (simulated) user can interac-tively teach a deployed GPT -3, substantially increasing its accuracy over the queries with different kinds of misunderstandings by the GPT 3, a step towards the low-cost utility enhancement for very large pre-trained LMs.

papers.title: On the Paradox of Learning to Reason from Data
papers.authors: Honghua Zhang,Liunian Harold Li,Tao Meng,Kai-Wei Chang,Guy Van den Broeck
papers.summary: This study pro-vides an explanation for this paradox: instead of learning to emulate the correct reasoning function, BERT has in fact learned statistical features that inherently exist in logical reasoning problems.

papers.title: When to Make Exceptions: Exploring Language Models as Accounts of Human Moral Judgment
papers.authors: Zhijing Jin,Sydney Levine,Fernando Gonzalez,Ojasv Kamal,Maarten Sap,Mrinmaya Sachan,Rada Mihalcea,J. Tenenbaum,B. Schölkopf
papers.summary: This paper presents a novel challenge set consisting of rule-breaking question answering (RBQA) of cases that involve potentially permissible rule- Breaking – inspired by recent moral psychology studies and proposes a novel moral chain of thought prompting strategy that combines the strengths of LLMs with theories of moral reasoning developed in cognitive science to predict human moral judgments.

papers.title: Impact of Pretraining Term Frequencies on Few-Shot Reasoning
papers.authors: Yasaman Razeghi,Robert L Logan IV,Matt Gardner,Sameer Singh
papers.summary: Overall, although LMs exhibit strong performance at few-shot numerical reasoning tasks, the results raise the question of how much models actually generalize beyond pretraining data, and researchers are encouraged to take thepretraining data into account when interpreting evaluation results.

papers.title: Beyond Distributional Hypothesis: Let Language Models Learn Meaning-Text Correspondence
papers.authors: Myeongjun Jang,Frank Mtumbuka,Thomas Lukasiewicz
papers.summary: A novel intermediate training task, names meaning-matching, designed to directly learn a meaning-text correspondence, is proposed that enables PLMs to learn lexical semantic information and is found to be a safe intermediate task that guarantees a similar or better performance of downstream tasks.

papers.title: MultiHiertt: Numerical Reasoning over Multi Hierarchical Tabular and Textual Data
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Yilun Zhao,Yunxiang Li,Chenying Li,Rui Zhang
papers.summary: A new large-scale benchmark, MultiHiertt, with QA pairs over Multi Hierarchical Tabular and Textual data is constructed and a novel QA model termed MT2Net is introduced, which first applies facts retrieving to extract relevant supporting facts from both tables and text and then uses a reasoning module to perform symbolic reasoning over retrieved facts.

papers.title: A Simple, Yet Effective Approach to Finding Biases in Code Generation
papers.authors: Spyridon Mouselinos,Mateusz Malinowski,H. Michalewski
papers.summary: This work shows that current code generation systems exhibit biases inherited from large language model backbones, which might leak into generated code under specific circumstances, and proposes a framework that automatically removes hints and exposes various biases that these code generation models use.

papers.title: Judicial knowledge-enhanced magnitude-aware reasoning for numerical legal judgment prediction
papers.authors: Sheng Bi,Zhiyao Zhou,Lu Pan,G. Qi

papers.title: MC-LSTM: Mass-Conserving LSTM
papers.authors: Pieter-Jan Hoedt,Frederik Kratzert,D. Klotz,Christina Halmich,Markus Holzleitner,G. Nearing,S. Hochreiter,G. Klambauer
papers.summary: This work proposes a novel Mass-Conserving LSTM (MC-LSTM), which sets a new state-of-the-art for neural arithmetic units at learning arithmetic operations, such as addition tasks, which have a strong conservation law, as the sum is constant over time.

papers.title: Asynchronous Neural Networks for Learning in Graphs
papers.authors: Lukas Faber,Roger Wattenhofer
papers.summary: It is proved that AMP can simulate synchronous GNNs and that it can theoretically distinguish any pair of graphs and experimentally validate AMP’s expressiveness.

papers.title: Learning Division with Neural Arithmetic Logic Modules
papers.authors: Bhumika Mistry,K. Farrahi,Jonathon Hare
papers.summary: It is shown that robustly learning division in a systematic manner remains a challenge even at the simplest level of dividing two numbers, and two novel approaches for division are proposed which are called the Neural Reciprocal Unit (NRU) and the Neural Multiplicative Reciproc Unit (NMRU).

papers.title: On the Abilities of Mathematical Extrapolation with Implicit Models
papers.authors: Juliette Decugis,Max Emerling,Ashwin Ganesh,Alicia Y. Tsai,L. Ghaoui
papers.summary: This paper compares the robustness of implicitly-defined and classical deep learning models on a series of mathematical extrapolation tasks, where the models are tested with out-of-distribution samples during inference time to showcase implicit models’ unique advantages for mathematics extrapolation thanks to their flexible and selective framework.

papers.title: Improving the Robustness of Neural Multiplication Units with Reversible Stochasticity
papers.authors: Bhumika Mistry,K. Farrahi,Jonathon Hare
papers.summary: It is shown that Neural Multiplication Units (NMUs) are unable to reliably learn tasks as simple as multiplying two inputs when given different training ranges, and stochasticity provides improved robustness with the potential to improve learned representations of upstream networks for numerical and image tasks.

papers.title: Learning from Mistakes: Using Mis-predictions as Harm Alerts in Language Pre-Training
papers.authors: Chen Xing,Wenhao Liu,Caiming Xiong
papers.summary: It is argued that mis-predictions can help locate such dominating patterns that harm language understanding and propose a new language pre-training method, MisPredictions as Harm Alerts (MPA), which expedites the pre- training of BERT and ELECTRA and improves their performances on downstream tasks.

papers.title: RICA: Evaluating Robust Inference Capabilities Based on Commonsense Axioms
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Pei Zhou,Rahul Khanna,Bill Yuchen Lin,Daniel Ho,J. Pujara,Xiang Ren
papers.summary: A new challenge, RICA: Robust Inference using Commonsense Axioms, that evaluates robust commonsense inference despite textual perturbations and shows that PTLMs perform no better than random guessing on the zero-shot setting, are heavily impacted by statistical biases, and are not robust to perturbation attacks.

papers.title: Measuring and Improving Consistency in Pretrained Language Models
papers.venue: Transactions of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Yanai Elazar,Nora Kassner,Shauli Ravfogel,Abhilasha Ravichander,E. Hovy,Hinrich Schütze,Yoav Goldberg
papers.summary: The creation of PARAREL, a high-quality resource of cloze-style query English paraphrases, and analysis of the representational spaces of PLMs suggest that they have a poor structure and are currently not suitable for representing knowledge in a robust way.

papers.title: Thinking Aloud: Dynamic Context Generation Improves Zero-Shot Reasoning Performance of GPT-2
papers.authors: Gregor Betz,Kyle Richardson,C. Voigt

papers.title: PROST: Physical Reasoning about Objects through Space and Time
papers.authors: Stephane T Aroca-Ouellette,Cory Paik,A. Roncone,Katharina Kann
papers.summary: It is demonstrated that state-of-the-art pretrained models are inadequate at physical reasoning: they are influenced by the order in which answer options are presented to them, they struggle when the superlative in a question is inverted, and increasing the amount of pretraining data and parameters only yields minimal improvements.

papers.title: CommonsenseQA 2.0: Exposing the Limits of AI through Gamification
papers.authors: Alon Talmor,Ori Yoran,Ronan Le Bras,Chandrasekhar Bhagavatula,Yoav Goldberg,Yejin Choi,Jonathan Berant
papers.summary: This work proposes gamiﬁcation as a framework for data construction and creates CommonsenseQA 2.0, which includes 14,343 yes/no questions, and demonstrates its difﬂculty for models that are orders-of-magnitude larger than the AI used in the game itself.

papers.title: RuleBERT: Teaching Soft Rules to Pre-Trained Language Models
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Mohammed Saeed,N. Ahmadi,Preslav Nakov,Paolo Papotti
papers.summary: This work introduces a classification task where, given facts and soft rules, thePLM should return a prediction with a probability for a given hypothesis, and proposes a revised loss function that enables the PLM to learn how to predict precise probabilities for the task.

papers.title: Knowledge Based Multilingual Language Model
papers.authors: Linlin Liu,Xin Li,Ruidan He,Lidong Bing,Shafiq R. Joty,Luo Si
papers.summary: This work presents a novel framework to pretrain knowledge based multilingual language models (KMLMs) by generating a large amount of code-switched synthetic sentences and reasoning-based multilingual training data using the Wikidata knowledge graphs and designing pretraining tasks to facilitate knowledge learning.

papers.title: LoNLI: An Extensible Framework for Testing Diverse Logical Reasoning Capabilities for NLI
papers.authors: Ishan Tarunesh,Somak Aditya,M. Choudhury
papers.summary: This work proposes an extensible framework to collectively yet categorically test diverse LOgical reasoning capabilities required for NLI (and by extension, NLU) and creates a semi-synthetic large test-bench that offers following utilities: individually test and analyze reasoning capabilities along 17 reasoning dimensions (including pragmatic reasoning).

papers.title: Knowledge-Augmented Methods for Natural Language Processing
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Chenguang Zhu,Yichong Xu,Xiang Ren,Bill Yuchen Lin,Meng Jiang,Wenhao Yu
papers.summary: This tutorial introduces the key steps in integrating knowledge into NLP, including knowledge grounding from text, knowledge representation and fusing, and introduces recent state-of-the-art applications in fusing knowledge into language understanding, language generation and commonsense reasoning.

papers.title: Improved Logical Reasoning of Language Models via Differentiable Symbolic Programming
papers.authors: Hanlin Zhang,Jian-Hui Huang,Ziyang Li,M. Naik,Eric Xing
papers.summary: DSR-LM is scalable, interpretable, and allows easy integration of prior knowledge, thereby supporting extensive symbolic programming to robustly derive a logical conclusion and leads to improved logical reasoning of pre-trained LMs.

papers.title: Can We Guide a Multi-Hop Reasoning Language Model to Incrementally Learn at Each Single-Hop?
papers.authors: Jesús Lovón-Melgarejo,Jose G. Moreno,Romaric Besançon,Olivier Ferret,L. Tamine
papers.summary: To endow PLMs with incremental reasoning skills, this work proposes a set of inference strategies on relevant facts and distractors allowing us to build automatically generated training datasets, and empirically shows the effectiveness of this proposal on multiple-choice question answering and reading comprehension.

papers.title: JAKET: Joint Pre-training of Knowledge Graph and Language Understanding
papers.authors: Donghan Yu,Chenguang Zhu,Yiming Yang,Michael Zeng
papers.summary: A novel joint pre-training framework, JAKET, to model both the knowledge graph and language, which enables the pre-trained model to easily adapt to unseen knowledge graphs in new domains.

papers.title: Enhancing Multilingual Language Model with Massive Multilingual Knowledge Triples
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Linlin Liu,Xin Li,Ruidan He,Lidong Bing,Shafiq R. Joty,Luo Si
papers.summary: This work explores methods to make better use of the multilingual annotation and language agnostic property of KG triples, and presents novel knowledge based multilingual language models (KMLMs) trained directly on the knowledge triples.

papers.title: Does Pre-training Induce Systematic Inference? How Masked Language Models Acquire Commonsense Knowledge
papers.venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Ian Porada,Alessandro Sordoni,J. C. Cheung
papers.summary: It is found generalization does not improve over the course of pre-training, suggesting that commonsense knowledge is acquired from surface-level, co-occurrence patterns rather than induced, systematic reasoning.

papers.title: On the data requirements of probing
papers.authors: Zining Zhu,Jixuan Wang,Bai Li,F. Rudzicz
papers.summary: A novel method to estimate the required number of data samples in such experiments is presented and, across several case studies, it is verified that the estimations have sufficient statistical power.

papers.title: Can Pre-trained Language Models Interpret Similes as Smart as Human?
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Qi He,Sijie Cheng,Zhixu Li,Rui Xie,Yanghua Xiao
papers.summary: This paper investigates the ability of PLMs in simile interpretation by designing a novel task named Simile Property Probing, and shows that PLMs can infer similes’ shared properties while still underperforming humans.

papers.title: Shepherd Pre-trained Language Models to Develop a Train of Thought: An Iterative Prompting Approach
papers.authors: Boshi Wang,Xiang Deng,Huan Sun
papers.summary: An iterative prompting framework, a new prompting paradigm which progressively elicits relevant knowledge from PLMs for multi-step inference tasks, and proposes an iterative context-aware prompter, which addresses limitations by learning to dynamically synthesize prompts conditioned on the current step’s contexts.

papers.title: Iteratively Prompt Pre-trained Language Models for Chain of Thought
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Boshi Wang,Xiang Deng,Huan Sun
papers.summary: An iterative prompting framework is explored, a new prompting paradigm which progressively elicits relevant knowledge from PLMs for multi-step inference by learning to dynamically synthesize prompts conditioned on the current step’s contexts.

papers.title: Knowledge Infused Decoding
papers.authors: Ruibo Liu,Guoqing Zheng,Shashank Gupta,Radhika Gaonkar,Chongyang Gao,Soroush Vosoughi,Milad Shokouhi,A. Awadallah
papers.summary: Knowledge Infused Decoding (KID)—a novel decoding algorithm for generative LMs, which dynamically infuses external knowledge into each step of the LM decoding, which maintains a local knowledge memory based on the current context, interacting with a dynamically created external knowledge trie, and continuously update the local memory as a knowledge-aware constraint to guide decoding via reinforcement learning.

papers.title: A Review on Language Models as Knowledge Bases
papers.authors: Badr AlKhamissi,Millicent Li,Asli Celikyilmaz,Mona T. Diab,Marjan Ghazvininejad
papers.summary: This paper presents a set of aspects that it is deemed an LM should have to fully act as a KB, and reviews the recent literature with respect to those aspects.

papers.title: GeoMLAMA: Geo-Diverse Commonsense Probing on Multilingual Pre-Trained Language Models
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Da Yin,Hritik Bansal,Masoud Monajatipoor,Liunian Harold Li,Kai-Wei Chang
papers.summary: Interestingly, it is found that larger multilingual PLMs variants do not necessarily store geo-diverse concepts better than its smaller variant; and a language may better probe knowledge about a non-native country than its native country.

papers.title: Learning Symbolic Rules for Reasoning in Quasi-Natural Language
papers.authors: Kaiyu Yang,Jia Deng
papers.summary: This work proposes MetaQNL, a “Quasi-Natural” language that can express both formal logic and natural language sentences, and MetaInduce, a learning algorithm that inducesMetaQNL rules from training data consisting of questions and answers, with or without intermediate reasoning steps.

papers.title: Induced Natural Language Rationales and Interleaved Markup Tokens Enable Extrapolation in Large Language Models
papers.authors: M. Bueno,Carlos Gemmel,Jeffrey Stephen Dalton,R. Lotufo,Rodrigo Nogueira
papers.summary: This work demonstrates that large language models can succeed in extrapolation without modifying their architecture or training procedure, and shows how generating step-by-step rationales and introducing marker tokens are both required for effective extrapolation.

papers.title: A Short Survey of Systematic Generalization
papers.authors: Yuanpeng Li
papers.summary: This survey includes systematic generalization and aory of how machine learning addresses it, and looks into sys- tematic generalization in language, vision, and VQA ﬁelds.

papers.title: Temporal Reasoning in Natural Language Inference
papers.authors: Siddharth Vashishtha,Adam Poliak,Yash Kumar Lal,Benjamin Van Durme,Aaron Steven White
papers.summary: Five new natural language inference (NLI) datasets focused on temporal reasoning are introduced and four existing datasets annotated for event duration and event ordering are recast into more than one million NLI examples.

papers.title: TR at SemEval-2020 Task 4: Exploring the Limits of Language-model-based Common Sense Validation
papers.authors: Don Teo
papers.summary: This paper examines the ability of large-scale pre-trained language models to distinguish commonsense from non-commonsense statements, and the utility of external resources that aim to supplement the world knowledge inherent in such language models, including commonsense knowledge graph embedding models, word concreteness ratings, and text-to-image generation models.

papers.title: DEER: A Data Efficient Language Model for Event Temporal Reasoning
papers.authors: Rujun Han,Xiang Ren,Nanyun Peng
papers.summary: This work proposes DEER, a language model that is trained to focus on event temporal relations and performs better under low-resource settings than original LMs and uses a generator-discriminator structure to reinforce the LMs' capability of event temporal reasoning.

papers.title: Open Temporal Relation Extraction for Question Answering
papers.venue: Conference on Automated Knowledge Base Construction
papers.authors: Chao Shang,Peng Qi,Guangtao Wang,Jing Huang,Youzheng Wu,Bowen Zhou
papers.summary: This paper decomposes each question into a question event and an open temporal relation (OTR) which is not pre-defined nor with timestamps, and ground the former in the context while sharing the representation of the latter across contexts.

papers.title: ESTER: A Machine Reading Comprehension Dataset for Reasoning about Event Semantic Relations
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Rujun Han,I-Hung Hsu,Jiao Sun,J. Baylón,Qiang Ning,D. Roth,Nanyun Peng

papers.title: ForecastQA: A Question Answering Challenge for Event Forecasting with Temporal Text Data
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Woojeong Jin,Suji Kim,Rahul Khanna,Dong-Ho Lee,Fred Morstatter,A. Galstyan,Xiang Ren
papers.summary: This work aims to formulate a task, construct a dataset, and provide benchmarks for developing methods for event forecasting with large volumes of unstructured text data, and introduces ForecastQA, a question-answering dataset consisting of 10,392 event forecasting questions, which have been collected and verified via crowdsourcing efforts.

papers.title: Temporal Reasoning on Implicit Events from Distant Supervision
papers.venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Ben Zhou,Kyle Richardson,Qiang Ning,Tushar Khot,Ashish Sabharwal,D. Roth
papers.summary: A neuro-symbolic temporal reasoning model, SymTime, is proposed, which exploits distant supervision signals from large-scale text and uses temporal rules to combine start times and durations to infer end times and generalizes to other temporal reasoning tasks.

papers.title: ECONET: Effective Continual Pretraining of Language Models for Event Temporal Reasoning
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Rujun Han,Xiang Ren,Nanyun Peng
papers.summary: A continual pre-training approach that equips PTLMs with targeted knowledge about event temporal relations and design self-supervised learning objectives to recover masked-out event and temporal indicators and to discriminate sentences from their corrupted counterparts.

papers.title: Conditional Generation of Temporally-ordered Event Sequences
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Shih-Ting Lin,Nathanael Chambers,Greg Durrett
papers.summary: A single model is proposed that addresses both temporal ordering, sorting given events into the order they occurred, and event infilling, predicting new events which fit into an existing temporally-ordered sequence.

papers.title: Microtask Detection
papers.authors: Ryen W. White,E. Nouri,James Woffinden-Luey,Mark J. Encarnación,S. Jauhar
papers.summary: This article introduces the novel challenge of microtask detection, and it presents machine-learned models for automatically determining which tasks are actionable and which of these actionable tasks are microtasks, which have implications for the design of systems to help people make the most of their time.

papers.title: AR-LSAT: Investigating Analytical Reasoning of Text
papers.authors: Wanjun Zhong,Siyuan Wang,Duyu Tang,Zenan Xu,Daya Guo,Jiahai Wang,Jian Yin,Ming Zhou,Nan Duan
papers.summary: This paper studies the challenge of analytical reasoning of text and introduces a new dataset consisting of questions from the Law School Admission Test from 1991 to 2016, and designs two different baselines which struggle to solve this task.

papers.title: Back to Square One: Artifact Detection, Training and Commonsense Disentanglement in the Winograd Schema
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Yanai Elazar,Hongming Zhang,Yoav Goldberg,D. Roth
papers.summary: It is suggested that the apparent progress on WS may not necessarily reflect progress in commonsense reasoning, and the observed progress is mostly due to the use of supervision in training WS models, which is not likely to successfully support all the required Commonsense reasoning skills and knowledge.

papers.title: ESTER: A Machine Reading Comprehension Dataset for Event Semantic Relation Reasoning
papers.authors: Rujun Han,I-Hung Hsu,Jiao Sun,J. Baylón,Qiang Ning,D. Roth,Nanyun Pen
papers.summary: ESTER, a comprehensive machine reading comprehension (MRC) dataset for Event Semantic Relation Reasoning is introduced, which study five most commonly used event semantic relations and formulate them as questionanswering tasks.

papers.title: CrossFit: A Few-shot Learning Challenge for Cross-task Generalization in NLP
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Qinyuan Ye,Bill Yuchen Lin,Xiang Ren
papers.summary: This paper presents the NLP Few-shot Gym, a repository of 160 diverse few-shot NLP tasks created from open-access NLP datasets and converted to a unified text-to-text format, and reveals that the few- shot learning ability on unseen tasks can be improved via an upstream learning stage using a set of seen tasks.

papers.title: Probing Language Models for Understanding of Temporal Expressions
papers.venue: BlackboxNLP Workshop on Analyzing and Interpreting Neural Networks for NLP
papers.authors: Shivin Thukral,Kunal Kukreja,Christian Kavouras
papers.summary: It is found that although large language models fine-tuned on MNLI have some basic perception of the order between points in time, at large, these models do not have a thorough understanding of the relation between temporal expressions.

papers.title: Exploring Universal Intrinsic Task Subspace via Prompt Tuning
papers.authors: Yujia Qin,Xiaozhi Wang,Yusheng Su,Yankai Lin,Ning Ding,Jing Yi,Weize Chen,Zhiyuan Liu,Juanzi Li,Lei Hou,Peng Li,Maosong Sun,Jie Zhou
papers.summary: Evidence is shown indicating that the adaptations of PLMs to various few-shot tasks can be reparameterized as optimizing only a few free parameters in a low-dimensional intrinsic task subspace, which may help to understand why PLMs could easily adapt to various NLP tasks with small-scale data.

papers.title: A Meta-framework for Spatiotemporal Quantity Extraction from Text
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Qiang Ning,Ben Zhou,Hao Wu,Haoruo Peng,Chuchu Fan,Matt Gardner
papers.summary: This paper formulates the NLP problem of spatiotemporal quantity extraction, and proposes the first meta-framework for solving it, which contains a formalism that decomposes the problem into several information extraction tasks, a shareable crowdsourcing pipeline, and transformer-based baseline models.

papers.title: KnowDA: All-in-One Knowledge Mixture Model for Data Augmentation in Few-Shot NLP
papers.authors: Yufei Wang,Jiayi Zheng,Can Xu,Xiubo Geng,Tao Shen,Chongyang Tao,Daxin Jiang
papers.summary: It is demonstrated that the proposed Knowledge Mixture enables pre-trained language models the capability of generating proper synthetic instances from scratch for complicated tasks (i.e., the data sample has long sequences or multiple sentences).

papers.title: Analytical Reasoning of Text
papers.authors: Wanjun Zhong,Siyuan Wang,Duyu Tang,Zenan Xu,Daya Guo,Yining Chen,Jiahai Wang,Jian Yin,Ming Zhou,Nan Duan
papers.summary: This paper studies the challenge of analytical reasoning of text and collects a new dataset consisting of questions from the Law School Admission Test from 1991 to 2016, and presents an approach dubbed ARM, which outperforms pre-trained models significantly.

papers.title: How about Time? Probing a Multilingual Language Model for Temporal Relations
papers.authors: Tommaso Caselli,Irene Dini,F. Dell’Orletta
papers.summary: This paper presents a comprehensive set of probing experiments using a multilingual language model, XLM-R, for temporal relation classification between events in four languages, and results show an advantage of contextualized embeddings over static ones and a detrimen- tal role of sentence level embeddeddings.

papers.title: Toward Building a Language Model for Understanding Temporal Commonsense
papers.authors: Mayuko Kimura,L. Pereira,Ichiro Kobayashi
papers.summary: This paper focuses on the development of language models for temporal commonsense inference over several pre-trained language models, and relies on multi-step fine-tuning using multiple corpora, and masked language modeling to predict masked temporal indicators that are crucial for temporal Commonsense reasoning.

papers.title: 20Q: Overlap-Free World Knowledge Benchmark for Language Models
papers.authors: Maxime De Bruyn,Ehsan Lotfi,Jeska Buhmann,Walter Daelemans
papers.summary: 20Q is introduced, a novel benchmark using the Twenty Questions game to evaluate world knowledge and common sense of language models and shows that in-context learning is inefficient for evaluating language models’ world knowledge — fine-tuning is necessary to show their true capabilities.

papers.title: Cross-Task Generalization via Natural Language Crowdsourcing Instructions
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Swaroop Mishra,Daniel Khashabi,Chitta Baral,Hannaneh Hajishirzi
papers.summary: This work introduces NATURAL INSTRUCTIONS, a dataset of 61 distinct tasks, their human-authored instructions, and 193k task instances, and adopts generative pre-trained language models to encode task-specific instructions along with input and generate task output.

papers.title: Time-Aware Language Models as Temporal Knowledge Bases
papers.venue: International Conference on Topology, Algebra and Categories in Logic
papers.authors: Bhuwan Dhingra,Jeremy R. Cole,Julian Martin Eisenschlos,D. Gillick,Jacob Eisenstein,William W. Cohen
papers.summary: This work proposes a simple technique for jointly modeling text with its timestamp that improves memorization of seen facts from the training time period, as well as calibration on predictions about unseen facts from future time periods and shows that models trained with temporal context can be efficiently "refreshed" as new data arrives.

papers.title: MetaICL: Learning to Learn In Context
papers.venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Sewon Min,M. Lewis,Luke Zettlemoyer,Hannaneh Hajishirzi
papers.summary: This work introduces MetaICL (Meta-training for In-Context Learning), a new meta-training framework for few-shot learning where a pretrained language model is tuned to do in-context learning on a large set of training tasks.

papers.title: Zero-shot Commonsense Question Answering with Cloze Translation and Consistency Optimization
papers.authors: Zi-Yi Dou,Nanyun Peng
papers.summary: Four translation methods that can translate natural questions into cloze-style sentences to better solicit commonsense knowledge from language models are investigated, including a syntactic-based model, an unsupervised neural model, and two supervised neural models.

papers.title: Commonsense Knowledge Reasoning and Generation with Pre-trained Language Models: A Survey
papers.authors: Prajjwal Bhargava,Vincent Ng
papers.summary: A survey of commonsense knowledge acquisition and reasoning tasks, the strengths and weaknesses of state-of-the-art pre-trained models for commonsense reasoning and generation as revealed by these tasks, and reflects on future research directions are presented.

papers.title: Go Back in Time: Generating Flashbacks in Stories with Event Temporal Prompts
papers.venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Rujun Han,Hong Chen,Yufei Tian,Nanyun Peng
papers.summary: A Plan-and-Write framework enhanced by reinforcement learning to generate storylines and stories end-to-end using structured storylines to encode events and their pair-wise temporal relations as **temporal prompts** that guide how stories should unfold temporally.

papers.title: KnowDA: All-in-One Knowledge Mixture Model for Data Augmentation in Low-Resource NLP
papers.authors: Yufei Wang,Jiayi Zheng,Can Xu,Xiubo Geng,Tao Shen,Chongyang Tao,Daxin Jiang
papers.summary: The goal of KoMT is to condense diverse NLP task-speciﬁc knowledge into the single KnowDA model (i.e., all-in-one) such that KnowDA could utilize these knowledge to quickly grasp the inherent synthesis law of the target task through limited training instances.

papers.title: Mitigating Reporting Bias in Semi-supervised Temporal Commonsense Inference with Probabilistic Soft Logic
papers.authors: Bibo Cai,Xiao Ding,Bowen Chen,L. Du,Ting Liu
papers.summary: A novel neural-logic based Soft Logic Enhanced Event Temporal Reasoning (SLEER) model is proposed for acquiring unbiased TCS knowledge, in which the complementary relationship among dimensions are explicitly represented as logic rules and modeled by t-norm fuzzy logics.

papers.title: Few-shot Adaptation Works with UnpredicTable Data
papers.authors: Jun Shern Chan,M. Pieler,Jonathan Jao,J. Scheurer,Ethan Perez
papers.summary: This work automatically extracting 413,299 tasks from internet tables - orders of magnitude more than the next-largest public datasets - and finds that narrow subsets of the authors' dataset sometimes outperform more diverse datasets.

papers.title: "John is 50 years old, can his son be 65?" Evaluating NLP Models' Understanding of Feasibility
papers.authors: Himanshu Gupta,Neeraj Varshney,Swaroop Mishra,Kuntal Kumar Pal,Saurabh Arjun Sawant,Kevin Scaria,Siddharth Goyal,Chitta Baral
papers.summary: This work introduces FeasibilityQA, a question-answering dataset involving binary classification (BCQ) and multi-choice multi-correct questions (MCQ) that test understanding of feasibility, and shows that even state-of-the-art models such as GPT-3, G PT-2, and T5 struggle to answer the feasibility questions correctly.

papers.title: Learning to Decompose: Hypothetical Question Decomposition Based on Comparable Texts
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Ben Zhou,Kyle Richardson,Xiaodong Yu,D. Roth
papers.summary: It is shown that with such intermediate pre-training, developing robust decomposition-based models for a diverse range of tasks becomes more feasible, and the model, DecompT5, improves 20% to 30% on two datasets, Overnight and TORQUE, over the baseline language model.

papers.title: Test of Time: Instilling Video-Language Models with a Sense of Time
papers.authors: Piyush Bagad,Makarand Tapaswi,Cees G. M. Snoek
papers.summary: This paper proposes a temporal adaptation recipe on top of one video-language model, VideoCLIP, based on post-pretraining on a small amount of video-text data, and conducts a zero-shot evaluation of the adapted models on six datasets for three downstream tasks which require a varying degree of time awareness.

papers.title: tieval: An Evaluation Framework for Temporal Information Extraction Systems
papers.authors: Hugo Sousa,A. Jorge,Ricardo Campos
papers.summary: T tieval, a Python library that provides a concise interface for importing different corpora and is equipped with domain-specific operations that facilitate system evaluation, is presented and its most relevant features are highlighted.

papers.title: tasksource: Structured Dataset Preprocessing Annotations for Frictionless Extreme Multi-Task Learning and Evaluation
papers.authors: Damien Sileo
papers.summary: This work identifies patterns across previous preprocessings, e.g. mapping of column names, and extraction of a specific sub-field from structured data in a column, and proposes a structured annotation framework that makes the authors' annotations fully exposed and not buried in unstructured code.

papers.title: Learning to Initialize: Can Meta Learning Improve Cross-task Generalization in Prompt Tuning?
papers.authors: Chengwei Qin,Shafiq R. Joty,Q. Li,Ruochen Zhao
papers.summary: Meta prompt tuning is studied to systematically explore how meta-learning can help improve (if it can) cross-task generalization in PT through learning to initialize the prompt embeddings from other relevant tasks and an in-depth analysis from the perspective of task similarity.

papers.title: Mining Numbers in Text: A Survey
papers.authors: Minoru Yoshida,K. Kita
papers.summary: A quick overview of the history and recent advances of the research of mining such relations between numerals and words found in text data is provided.

papers.title: NQuAD: 70,000+ Questions for Machine Comprehension of the Numerals in Text
papers.venue: International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management
papers.authors: Chung-Chi Chen,Hen-Hsen Huang,Hsin-Hsi Chen
papers.summary: A Numeral-related Question Answering Dataset, NQuAD, for fine-grained numeracy, is presented, and several baselines for future works are proposed and it is shown that N QuAD is more challenging than the numeral- related questions in other datasets.

papers.title: Enhancing Knowledge Bases with Quantity Facts
papers.authors: Vinh Thinh Ho,D. Stepanova,Dragan Milchevski,Jannik Strötgen,G. Weikum
papers.summary: A recall-oriented approach to close the gap in knowledge-base coverage, based on iterative learning for extracting quantity facts, with two novel contributions to boost recall for KB augmentation without sacrificing the quality standards of the knowledge base.

papers.title: Evaluating Prompts Across Multiple Choice Tasks In a Zero-Shot Setting
papers.authors: Gabriel Orlanski
papers.summary: Collect and standardize prompts from a diverse range of tasks for use with tasks they were not designed for and evaluate these prompts across multiple choice datasets for a quantitative analysis of how certain attributes of a prompt affect performance.

papers.title: On the Computational Power of Transformers and Its Implications in Sequence Modeling
papers.venue: Conference on Computational Natural Language Learning
papers.authors: S. Bhattamishra,Arkil Patel,Navin Goyal
papers.summary: This paper provides an alternate and simpler proof to show that vanilla Transformers are Turing-complete and proves that Transformers with only positional masking and without any positional encoding are also Turing- complete.

papers.title: Neuro-Symbolic Representations for Video Captioning: A Case for Leveraging Inductive Biases for Vision and Language
papers.authors: Hassan Akbari,H. Palangi,Jianwei Yang,Sudha Rao,Asli Celikyilmaz,Roland Fernandez,P. Smolensky,Jianfeng Gao,Shih-Fu Chang
papers.summary: A new model architecture for learning multi-modal neuro-symbolic representations for video captioning using a dictionary learning-based method that incorporates modality-specific inductive biases for the captioning task is proposed.

papers.title: Increasing Learning Efficiency of Self-Attention Networks through Direct Position Interactions, Learnable Temperature, and Convoluted Attention
papers.authors: Philipp Dufter,Martin Schmitt,Hinrich Schütze
papers.summary: This work investigates three modifications to SANs: direct position interactions, learnable temperature, and convoluted attention that enable faster learning, i.e., higher accuracies after fewer update steps.

papers.title: MuseMorphose: Full-Song and Fine-Grained Music Style Transfer with Just One Transformer VAE
papers.authors: Shih-Lun Wu,Yi-Hsuan Yang
papers.summary: Experiments show that MuseMorphose outperforms recurrent neural network (RNN) based baselines on numerous widely-used metrics for style transfer tasks.

papers.title: Rethinking the Design Principles of Robust Vision Transformer
papers.authors: Xiaofeng Mao,Gege Qi,Yuefeng Chen,Xiaodan Li,Shaokai Ye,Yuan He,Hui Xue
papers.summary: RVT is a new vision transformer, which has superior performance and strong robustness, and two new plug-and-play techniques called position-aware attention rescaling and patch-wise augmentation to train the authors' RVT are proposed.

papers.title: On Scalar Embedding of Relative Positions in Attention Models
papers.authors: Junshuang Wu,Richong Zhang,Yongyi Mao,Junfan Chen
papers.summary: This work shows that SRPE in attention has an elegant probabilistic interpretation and proposes a new SRPE (AT5) that adopts a learnable bucketization protocol and automatically adapts to the dependency range specific to the learning task.

papers.title: Transformer with Syntactic Position Encoding for Machine Translation
papers.venue: Recent Advances in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Yikuan Xie,Wenyong Wang,Mingqian Du,Qing He
papers.summary: This work proposes global positional encoding for dependency tree, a new scheme that facilitates syntactic relation modeling between any two words with keeping exactness and without immediate neighbor constraint, which is more effective than existing approaches.

papers.title: DEBERTA: DECODING-ENHANCED BERT
papers.authors: Pengcheng He,Xiaodong Liu,Jianfeng Gao,Weizhu Chen
papers.summary: A new model architecture DeBERTa (Decoding-enhanced BERT with disentangled attention) is proposed that improves the BERT and RoBERTa models using two novel techniques that significantly improve the efficiency of model pre-training and the performance of both natural language understand (NLU) and natural langauge generation (NLG) downstream tasks.

papers.title: Explore Better Relative Position Embeddings from Encoding Perspective for Transformer Models
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Anlin Qu,Jianwei Niu,Shasha Mo
papers.summary: This paper investigates the potential problems in Shaw-R PE and XL-RPE, and proposes two novel RPEs called Low-level Fine-grained High-level Coarse- grained (LFHC) RPE and Gaussian Cumulative Distribution Function (GCDF) R PE.

papers.title: Integrating Tree Path in Transformer for Code Representation
papers.authors: Han Peng,Ge Li,Wenhan Wang,Yunfei Zhao,Zhi Jin
papers.summary: This paper investigates two representative path encoding methods shown in previous research work and integrates them into the attention module of Transformer, leading to the novel state-of-theart representation model TPTrans, which finally outperforms strong baselines.

papers.title: On Position Embeddings in BERT O N P OSITION E MBEDDINGS IN BERT
papers.authors: Jakob Grue

papers.title: DeBERTa: Decoding-enhanced BERT with Disentangled Attention
papers.authors: Pengcheng He,Xiaodong Liu,Jianfeng Gao,Weizhu Chen
papers.summary: A new model architecture DeBERTa (Decoding-enhanced BERT with disentangled attention) is proposed that improves the BERT and RoBERTa models using two novel techniques that significantly improve the efficiency of model pre-training and performance of downstream tasks.

papers.title: MaX-DeepLab: End-to-End Panoptic Segmentation with Mask Transformers
papers.authors: Huiyu Wang,Yukun Zhu,Hartwig Adam,A. Yuille,Liang-Chieh Chen
papers.summary: MaX-DeepLab, the first end-to-end model for panoptic segmentation, is presented, and shows a significant 7.1% PQ gain in the box-free regime on the challenging COCO dataset, closing the gap between box-based and box- free methods for the first time.

papers.title: Shortformer: Better Language Modeling using Shorter Inputs
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Ofir Press,Noah A. Smith,M. Lewis
papers.summary: This work identifies conditions where shorter inputs are not harmful, and achieves perplexity and efficiency improvements through two new methods that decrease input length, and shows how to improve the efficiency of recurrence methods in transformers.

papers.title: NRTSI: Non-Recurrent Time Series Imputation for Irregularly-sampled Data
papers.authors: Siyuan Shan,Junier B. Oliva
papers.summary: This work views the imputation task from the perspective of permutation equivariant modeling of sets and proposes a novel imputation model called NRTSI without any recurrent modules, which achieves state-of-the-art performance across a wide range of commonly used time series imputation benchmarks.

papers.title: Revisiting Language Encoding in Learning Multilingual Representations
papers.authors: Shengjie Luo,Kaiyuan Gao,Shuxin Zheng,Guolin Ke,Di He,Liwei Wang,Tie-Yan Liu
papers.summary: This paper revisits the use of language embedding and identifies several problems in the existing formulations and proposes a new approach called Cross-lingual Language Projection (XLP), which achieves the purpose of appropriately encoding “language” in a multilingual Transformer model.

papers.title: A Minimalist Dataset for Systematic Generalization of Perception, Syntax, and Semantics
papers.authors: Qing Li,Siyuan Huang,Yining Hong,Yixin Zhu,Y. Wu,Song-Chun Zhu
papers.summary: Models show a gap toward human-level generalization when tested with new concepts in a few-shot setting, and the results suggest that current models still struggle in extrapolation to long-range syntactic dependency and semantics.

papers.title: Demystifying the Better Performance of Position Encoding Variants for Transformer
papers.authors: Pu-Chin Chen,Henry Tsai,Srinadh Bhojanapalli,Hyung Won Chung,Yin-Wen Chang,Chun-Sung Ferng
papers.summary: This work demonstrates a simple yet effective way to encode position and segment into the Transformer models and performs on par with SOTA on GLUE, XTREME and WMT benchmarks while saving computation costs.

papers.title: A Simple and Effective Positional Encoding for Transformers
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Pu-Chin Chen,Henry Tsai,Srinadh Bhojanapalli,Hyung Won Chung,Yin-Wen Chang,Chun-Sung Ferng
papers.summary: This work introduces Decoupled Positional Attention for Transformers (DIET), a simple yet effective mechanism to encode position and segment information into the Transformer models that has faster training and inference time, while achieving competitive performance on GLUE, XTREME and WMT benchmarks.

papers.title: RoFormer: Enhanced Transformer with Rotary Position Embedding
papers.authors: Jianlin Su,Yu Lu,Shengfeng Pan,Bo Wen,Yunfeng Liu
papers.summary: This paper investigates various methods to integrate positional information into the learning process of transformer-based language models and proposes a novel method named Rotary Position Embedding (RoPE), which encodes the absolute position with a rotation matrix and meanwhile incorporates the explicit relative position dependency in self-attention formulation.

papers.title: MuseMorphose: Full-Song and Fine-Grained Piano Music Style Transfer with One Transformer VAE
papers.authors: Shih-Lun Wu,Yi-Hsuan Yang
papers.summary: Experiments show that MuseMorphose outperforms recurrent neural network based baselines on numerous widely-used metrics for style transfer tasks, and is interested in bringing the two together to construct a single model that exhibits both strengths.

papers.title: Relative Positional Encoding for Transformers with Linear Complexity
papers.authors: A. Liutkus,Ondřej Cífka,Shih-Lun Wu,Umut Simsekli,Yi-Hsuan Yang,Gaël Richard
papers.summary: Stochastic Positional Encoding is presented as a way to generate PE that can be used as a replace-ment to the classical additive (sinusoidal) PE and provably behaves like RPE.

papers.title: The Case for Translation-Invariant Self-Attention in Transformer-Based Language Models
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Ulme Wennberg,G. Henter
papers.summary: Analysis of position embeddings of existing language models finds strong evidence of translation invariance, which leads to translation-invariant self-attention (TISA), which accounts for the relative position between tokens in an interpretable fashion without needing conventional position embedDings.

papers.title: CAPE: Encoding Relative Positions with Continuous Augmented Positional Embeddings
papers.authors: T. Likhomanenko,Qiantong Xu,Ronan Collobert,Gabriel Synnaeve,A. Rogozhnikov
papers.summary: This paper proposes an augmentation-based approach (CAPE) for absolute positional embeddings, which keeps the advantages of both absolute and relative positions and leads to better generalization performance as well as increased stability with respect to training hyper-parameters.

papers.title: Do Transformers Really Perform Bad for Graph Representation?
papers.authors: Chengxuan Ying,Tianle Cai,Shengjie Luo,Shuxin Zheng,Guolin Ke,Di He,Yanming Shen,Tie-Yan Liu
papers.summary: This paper presents Graphormer, which is built upon the standard Transformer architecture, and could attain excellent results on a broad range of graph representation learning tasks, especially on the recent OGB Large-Scale Challenge.

papers.title: Convolutions and Self-Attention: Re-interpreting Relative Positions in Pre-trained Language Models
papers.venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Tyler A. Chang,Yifan Xu,Weijian Xu,Z. Tu
papers.summary: Composite attention is proposed, which unites previous relative position encoding methods under a convolutional framework, and finds that convolutions consistently improve performance on multiple downstream tasks, replacing absolute position embeddings.

papers.title: Do Large Scale Molecular Language Representations Capture Important Structural Information?
papers.authors: Jerret Ross,Brian M. Belgodere,Vijil Chenthamarakshan,Inkit Padhi,Youssef Mroueh,Payel Das
papers.summary: Experiments show that the learned molecular representation, MOLFORMER, performs competitively, when compared to existing graph-based and fingerprint-based supervised learning baselines, on the challenging tasks of predicting properties of QM8 and QM9 molecules.

papers.title: Stable, Fast and Accurate: Kernelized Attention with Relative Positional Encoding
papers.authors: Shengjie Luo,Shanda Li,Tianle Cai,Di He,Dinglan Peng,Shuxin Zheng,Guolin Ke,Liwei Wang,Tie-Yan Liu
papers.summary: A novel way to accelerate attention calculation for Transformers with RPE on top of the kernelized attention using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), and it is demonstrated that properly using relative positional encoding can mitigate the training instability problem of vanilla Kernelized attention.

papers.title: Bootstrap Representation Learning for Segmentation on Medical Volumes and Sequences
papers.authors: Zejian Chen,Wei Zhuo,Tianfu Wang,Wufeng Xue,Dong Ni
papers.summary: This work proposed an asymmetric network with an attention-guided predictor to enforce distance-specific prediction and supervision on slices within and across volumes/sequences and introduced a novel prototype-based foreground-background calibration module to enhance representation consistency.

papers.title: Rethinking Positional Encoding
papers.authors: Jianqiao Zheng,Sameera Ramasinghe,S. Lucey
papers.summary: It is shown that alternative non-Fourier embedding functions can indeed be used for positional encoding and that their performance is entirely determined by a trade-off between the stable rank of the embedded matrix and the distance preservation between embedded coordinates.

papers.title: Lighter and Better: Low-Rank Decomposed Self-Attention Networks for Next-Item Recommendation
papers.venue: Annual International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval
papers.authors: Xinyan Fan,Zheng Liu,Jianxun Lian,Wayne Xin Zhao,Xing Xie,Ji-Rong Wen
papers.summary: This work introduces the low-rank decomposed self-attention, which projects user's historical items into a small constant number of latent interests and leverages item-to-interest interaction to generate the context-aware representation and designs the decoupled position encoding, which models the sequential relations between items more precisely.

papers.title: Variable-Length Music Score Infilling via XLNet and Musically Specialized Positional Encoding
papers.venue: International Society for Music Information Retrieval Conference
papers.authors: Chin-Jui Chang,Chun-Yi Lee,Yi-Hsuan Yang
papers.summary: A new self-attention based model for music score infilling, i.e., to generate a polyphonic music sequence that fills in the gap between given past and future contexts, that can infill a variable number of notes for different time spans is proposed.

papers.title: The Devil is in the Detail: Simple Tricks Improve Systematic Generalization of Transformers
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: R. Csordás,Kazuki Irie,J. Schmidhuber
papers.summary: By revisiting model configurations as basic as scaling of embeddings, early stopping, relative positional embedding, and Universal Transformer variants, this work can drastically improve the performance of Transformers on systematic generalization.

papers.title: Shatter: An Efficient Transformer Encoder with Single-Headed Self-Attention and Relative Sequence Partitioning
papers.authors: Ran Tian,Joshua Maynez,Ankur P. Parikh
papers.summary: An alternative self-attention architecture, Shatter, that more efficiently encodes sequence information by softly partitioning the space of relative positions and applying different value matrices to different parts of the sequence, making the cost of pretraining much more affordable.

papers.title: Ultra-high Resolution Image Segmentation via Locality-aware Context Fusion and Alternating Local Enhancement
papers.authors: Wenxi Liu,Qi Li,Xin Lin,Weixiang Yang,Shengfeng He,Yuanlong Yu
papers.summary: This paper introduces a novel locality-aware context fusion based segmentation model to process local patches, where the relevance between local patch and its various contexts are jointly and complementarily utilized to handle the semantic regions with large variations.

papers.title: The Impact of Positional Encodings on Multilingual Compression
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Vinit Ravishankar,Anders Søgaard
papers.summary: While sinusoidal positional encodings were designed for monolingual applications, they are particularly useful in multilingual language models, because they were explicitly designed to facilitate compositionality by allowing linear projections over arbitrary time steps.

papers.title: Multiplicative Position-aware Transformer Models for Language Understanding
papers.authors: Zhiheng Huang,Davis Liang,Peng Xu,Bing Xiang
papers.summary: It is shown that the proposed embedding method, which served as a drop-in replacement of the default absolute position embedding, can improve the RoberTa-base and RoBERTa-large models on SQuAD1.1 and SQuad2.0 datasets.

papers.title: Learning to Iteratively Solve Routing Problems with Dual-Aspect Collaborative Transformer
papers.authors: Yining Ma,Jingwen Li,Zhiguang Cao,Wen Song,Le Zhang,Zhenghua Chen,Jing Tang
papers.summary: This paper presents a novel Dual-Aspect Collaborative Transformer to learn embeddings for the node and positional features separately, instead of fusing them together as done in existing ones, so as to avoid potential noises and incompatible correlations.

papers.title: Relative Molecule Self-Attention Transformer
papers.authors: Lukasz Maziarka,Dawid Majchrowski,Tomasz Danel,Piotr Gainski,J. Tabor,I. Podolak,Pawel M. Morkisz,Stanislaw Jastrzebski
papers.summary: Relative Molecule Attention Transformer (R-MAT) is identified: a novel Transformer-based model based on the developed self-attention layer that achieves state-of-the-art or very competitive results across a wide range of molecule property prediction tasks.

papers.title: SwinTrack: A Simple and Strong Baseline for Transformer Tracking
papers.authors: Liting Lin,Heng Fan,Yong Xu,Haibin Ling
papers.summary: This paper proposes a simple yet efﬁcient fully-attentional tracker, dubbed SwinTrack, within classic Siamese framework that leverages the Transformer architecture, enabling better feature interactions for tracking than pure CNN or hybrid CNN-Transformer frameworks.

papers.title: Probing the Role of Positional Information in Vision-Language Models
papers.authors: Philipp J. Rösch,Jindřich Libovický
papers.summary: A case study of LXMERT, a state-of-the-art VL model, which probes the use of the PI in the representation and study its effect on Visual Question Answering, it is shown that the model is not capable of leveraging the PI for the image-text matching task on a challenge set where only position differs.

papers.title: S TRUCTURE -A WARE T RANSFORMER P OLICY FOR I NHOMOGENEOUS M ULTI -T ASK R EINFORCEMENT L EARNING
papers.authors: Sunghoon Hong,Deunsol Yoon,Kee-Eung Kim
papers.summary: It is empirically show that the morphological information is crucial for modular reinforcement learning, substantially outperforming prior state-of-the-art methods on multi-task learning as well as transfer learning settings with different state and action space dimensions.

papers.title: Positional Attention Guided Transformer-like Architecture for Visual Question Answering
papers.authors: Aihua Mao,Zhi Yang,Ken Lin,Jun-ying Xuan,Yong-Jin Liu
papers.summary: A novel positional attention guided Transformer-like architecture which can adaptively extracts positional information within and across the visual and language modalities, and use this information to guide high-level interactions in inter- and intra- modality information flows is proposed.

papers.title: Molformer: Large Scale Chemical Language Representations Capture Molecular Structure and Properties
papers.authors: Jerret Ross,Brian M. Belgodere,V. Chenthamarakshan,Inkit Padhi,Youssef Mroueh,Payel Das
papers.summary: Experiments show that utilizing the learned molecular representation outperforms existing baselines on downstream tasks, including supervised and self-supervised graph neural net baselines and language models, on several classiﬁcation and regression tasks from ten benchmark datasets while performing competitively on two others.

papers.title: Graph Hawkes Transformer for Extrapolated Reasoning on Temporal Knowledge Graphs
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Haohai Sun,Shangyi Geng,Jialu Zhong,Han Hu,Kun He
papers.summary: A Graph Hawkes Transformer (GHT) is proposed, which combines two variants of Transformer, which capture the instantaneous structural information and temporal evolution information, respectively, and a new relational continuous-time encoding function to facilitate feature evolution with the Hawkes process.

papers.title: Rethinking Positional Encoding in Tree Transformer for Code Representation
papers.venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
papers.authors: Han Peng,Ge Li,Yunfei Zhao,Zhi Jin
papers.summary: This work proposes a novel tree Transformer encoding node positions based on a new description method for tree structures that outperforms strong baselines on code summarization and completion tasks across two languages, demonstrating the model’s effectiveness.

papers.title: Position Information in Transformers: An Overview
papers.authors: Philipp Dufter,Martin Schmitt,Hinrich Schütze
papers.summary: An overview and theoretical comparison of existing methods to incorporate position information into Transformer models is provided and what characteristics of an application should be taken into account when selecting a position encoding is indicated.

papers.title: Towards Robust Vision Transformer
papers.authors: Xiaofeng Mao,Gege Qi,Yuefeng Chen,Xiaodan Li,Ranjie Duan,Shaokai Ye,Yuan He,Hui Xue
papers.summary: Robust Vision Transformer (RVT) is proposed, which is a new vision transformer and has superior performance with strong robustness and generalization ability compared with previous ViTs and state-of-the-art CNNs.

papers.title: A Survey of Transformers
papers.authors: Tianyang Lin,Yuxin Wang,Xiangyang Liu,Xipeng Qiu
papers.summary: This survey provides a comprehensive review of various Transformer variants and proposes a new taxonomy of X-formers from three perspectives: architectural modification, pre-training, and applications.

papers.title: Large-scale chemical language representations capture molecular structure and properties
papers.authors: Jerret Ross,Brian M. Belgodere,V. Chenthamarakshan,Inkit Padhi,Youssef Mroueh,Payel Das
papers.summary: Encouraging evidence is provided that large-scale molecular language models can capture sufficient chemical and structural information to predict various distinct molecular properties, including quantum-chemical properties.

papers.title: PiSLTRc: Position-Informed Sign Language Transformer With Content-Aware Convolution
papers.authors: Pan Xie,Mengyi Zhao,Xiaohui Hu
papers.summary: This work proposes a new model architecture, namely PiSLTRc, with two distinctive characteristics: content-aware and position-aware convolution layers, thus generating robust neighborhood-enhanced sign representation and achieves state-of-the-art performance on translation quality with $+1.6$ BLEU improvements.

papers.title: Train Short, Test Long: Attention with Linear Biases Enables Input Length Extrapolation
papers.authors: Ofir Press,Noah A. Smith,M. Lewis
papers.summary: This work shows that extrapolation can be enabled by simply changing the position representation method, though it finds that current methods do not allow for efficient extrapolation, and introduces a simpler and more efficient position method, Attention with Linear Biases (ALiBi).

papers.title: Transformers in Time Series: A Survey
papers.authors: Qingsong Wen,Tian Zhou,Chao Zhang,Weiqiu Chen,Ziqing Ma,Junchi Yan,Liang Sun
papers.summary: This paper systematically review Transformer schemes for time series modeling by highlighting their strengths as well as limitations, and is the first work to comprehensively and systematically summarize the recent advances of Transformers for modeling time series data.

papers.title: FastRPB: a Scalable Relative Positional Encoding for Long Sequence Tasks
papers.authors: Maksim Zubkov,Daniil Gavrilov
papers.summary: Improved Linear Transformer with Shift-Invariant Kernel Function SIKF and FastRPB1 which stands for Fast Relative Positional Bias, which efficiently adds positional information to self-attention using Fast Fourier Transformation, which significantly outperforms another efficient positional encodings method in accuracy.

papers.title: LGT-Net: Indoor Panoramic Room Layout Estimation with Geometry-Aware Transformer Network
papers.authors: Zhigang Jiang,Zhongzheng Xiang,Jinhua Xu,Mingbi Zhao
papers.summary: This work proposes an efficient network, LGT-Net, for room layout estimation, which contains a novel Transformer architecture called SWG-Transformer to model geometry relations, and designs a novel relative position embedding of Transformer to enhance the spatial identification ability for the panorama.

papers.title: Visual Abductive Reasoning
papers.authors: Chen Liang,Wenguan Wang,Tianfei Zhou,Yi Yang
papers.summary: A new task and dataset, Visual Abductive Reasoning (VAR), for examining abductive reasoning ability of machine intelligence in everyday visual situations, and devise a strong baseline model, REASONER (causal-and-cascaded reasoning Transformer), which surpasses many famous video-language models, while still being far behind human performance.

papers.title: Causal Transformer for Estimating Counterfactual Outcomes
papers.authors: Valentyn Melnychuk,Dennis Frauen,S. Feuerriegel
papers.summary: A novel Causal Transformer for estimating counterfactual outcomes over time that aims to learn adversarial balanced representations, so that they are predictive of the next outcome but non-predictive of the current treatment assignment.

papers.title: Dynamic Position Encoding for Transformers
papers.authors: Joyce Zheng,Mehdi Rezagholizadeh,P. Passban
papers.summary: This paper proposes a novel architecture with new position embeddings that take the order of the target words into consideration and generates new embedDings to refine each word’s position information as dynamic position encoding (DPE).

papers.title: DecBERT: Enhancing the Language Understanding of BERT with Causal Attention Masks
papers.authors: Ziyang Luo,Yadong Xi,Jing Ma,Zhiwei Yang,Xiao-Xi Mao,Changjie Fan,Rongsheng Zhang
papers.summary: This work focuses on improving the position encoding ability of BERT with the causal attention masks, and proposes a new pre-trained language model DecBERT and evaluates it on the GLUE benchmark.

papers.title: ChapterBreak: A Challenge Dataset for Long-Range Language Models
papers.venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
papers.authors: Simeng Sun,Katherine Thai,Mohit Iyyer
papers.summary: This work introduces C HAPTER B REAK, a challenge dataset that provides an LRLM with a long segment from a narrative that ends at a chapter boundary and asks it to distinguish the beginning of the ground-truth next chapter from a set of negative segments sampled from the same narrative.
